info.game_comments:
2006 Celebrity Jeopardy! game 3.
From Radio City Music Hall in New York City.
Law & Order's signature "doink doink" sound used as "end-of-round" signal to end the Jeopardy! Round.

(2, 1).clue: This lady richly deserves her pedestal; the first ticker-tape parade was held for her 1886 dedication

(3, 1).clue: Will you still need me when I'm this Roman numeral?LXIV

(4, 1).clue: "Shout! The Mod Musical" takes us through this decade with songs like "Downtown" & "Goldfinger"

(5, 1).clue: During WWI, this president's wife used sheep to trim the White House lawn

(6, 1).clue: This current SUV line began in 1935 as an 8-passenger, all-steel wagon built on a Chevy truck chassis

(1, 2).clue: The Tam-o'-shanter & the Glengarry are popular men's hats from this U.K. country

(2, 2).clue: 2 NYC ticker-tape parades didn't gain the Shah popularity in this country where he was deposed in 1979

(4, 2).clue: (Before the clue is given, Toni Award-nominated actress Carolee Carmello from the Broadway play Mamma Mia! helps with the clue.)"Ooh-ooh-ooh-ooh  /You can dance /You can jive /Having the time of your life /Ooh-ooh-ooh, see that girl /Watch that scene /Dig in the dancing queen /""Dancing Queen" is one of many hit songs in "Mamma Mia!" that were originally made famous by this Swedish group

(5, 2).clue: Karl Dahlman built a rotary-blade one of these machines that ran like a hovercraft, on a cushion of air

(6, 2).clue: This former SUV model from Honda sounds like something you need when you travel abroad

(1, 3).clue: The name of this high-crowned, very wide-brimmed men's hat from Mexico comes from the Spanish word for "shade"

(2, 3).clue: In 1927 he returned to a hero's welcome less than a month after leaving Long Island for Paris

(5, 3).clue: Also known as finger grass, a creeping weed of the genus Digitaria is better known by this "grouchy" name

(6, 3).clue: Subaru has a 7-passenger SUV named for this Manhattan neighborhood that's home to a film festival

(1, 4).clue: 18th century frontiersman Daniel Boone is often depicted wearing one of these hats made from an animal

(2, 4).clue: In 1951 it was the turn of David Ben-Gurion, the first prime minister of this country

(3, 4).clue: TV secret agent Maxwell Smart's beautiful agent wife:XCIX

(5, 4).clue: Keeping your lawn healthy might require adding a fertilizer that includes this chemical element, symbol N

(1, 5).clue: In the movies, this great fictional British detective often wore a hat called a deerstalker

(2, 5).clue: Unemployment started with a bang when this 5-star general got a parade after being fired by Truman in 1951

(5, 5).clue: Unlike a perennial, which will bloom year after year, this type of plant goes through its life cycle in one year

(1, 1).clue: In the early 1900s, William Bragg used this type of ray to try to photograph the structure of molecules

(2, 1).clue: Kramer, on this show:"I'm taping Canadian Parliament, you know, on C-SPAN"

(3, 1).clue: Brands of this condiment include Colman's, Gulden's & Plochman's

(4, 1).clue: "Team of Rivals" by Doris Kearns Goodwin is about Lincoln's bringing political foes into this advisory body

(5, 1).clue: When the Mad Hatter says, "No room!", you retort, "There's plenty of room!" as you're playing this title girl

(1, 2).clue: An electron type of this optical scientific instrument is used to magnify molecules for study

(2, 2).clue: Megan Mullally, as Karen on this show:"You say potato, I say vodka"

(3, 2).clue: A Reuben sandwich is usually served with this fermented cabbage dish

(4, 2).clue: This controversial bestseller by Dan Brown begins with a murder in the Louvre

(5, 2).clue: Try to look mysterious when you say, "I never drink... wine"--you're playing this spooky guy

(1, 3).clue: Gregor Mendel famously found a mathematical basis for inheritance by studying this legume, without the princess

(2, 3).clue: David Hyde Pierce, on this NBC sitcom: "Her lips were saying 'No' but her eyes were saying 'Read my lips'"

(4, 3).clue: In the 1980s he was quite at home on the bestseller list with books like "Misery", "Cujo" & "Christine"

(5, 3).clue: You're playing this saint, so you say, "I hear voices telling me what to do"

(1, 4).clue: Chromosomes carry these basic units of heredity, not discovered by Levi Strauss

(2, 4).clue: "Women--can't live with 'em ...pass the beer nuts", said Norm on this show

(3, 4).clue: It sounds like a "Taxi" character, but it's really a potato pancake

(4, 4).clue: She wasn't portrayed as the dearest of moms in the 1978 memoir "Mommie Dearest"

(2, 5).clue: An address label error led to a character on this show receiving a TV guide as "Ms. Chanandler Bong"

(3, 5).clue: If you're having gravlax, the last 3 letters should tell you that you're eating this 6-letter fish

(0, 0).clue: Robert Armin played the role of the fool in "As You Like It", in "Twelfth Night" & in this tragedy 1st published in 1608
